issue.title: NAT-PMP port forwarding support
issue.body:
After repeated issues with libminiupnpc's security we disabled uPNP by default since release 0.11.1.

However this means that by default there is no port forwarding, resulting in nodes not being reachable for incoming connections by default (unless they use tor), and a reduction in the number of externally reachable nodes compared to total nodes.

NAT-PMP ([RFC 6886](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6886)) is another common automatic port forwarding protocol that would be much less risky than UPnP, because it uses fixed-size UDP packets instead of XML parsing. It would be fairly straightforward to support that without introducing a new dependency.

(NAT-PMP was succeeded by PCP, or [RFC 6887](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6887) which is backwards compatible, probably preferable to support the lowest common denominator)

issue.title: Suggestion: move p2p out of grin
issue.body:
The primary goal should be a stable, low latency p2p to propagate mined blocks.
Discovery can always be bolted on afterwards. Reliability is the hard part.

Maybe get NAT-traversal and large anonymity set "for free" by using some existing popular network protocol as a base.

WebRTC could be interesting, and maybe make it easier to create web wallets.

Moving p2p out into its own "service" allows `grin server` to use that service as a caching layer, and possibly one p2p service with high bandwidth could be used by several mobile/embedded validating grin servers.
Interfacing could happen through grin API endpoints.

__What endpoints would then need to be added?__

Rationale:
- no devs are comfy with existing p2p built on futures
- still lots to do on p2p
- there's no mature rust p2p code to lean on
  (in rust, the only p2p crate I've found is named crust and is missing features and having bugs that makes it a no-go for grin for the next few months at least)
- enables reuse, to get NAT-traversal, web browser compat, mature p2p base

Cons:
 - current code mostly works for non NAT:ed users
 - already have a test: peer_handshake
 - force-adds API-endpoints
 - cutting grin into smaller pieces

Pros:
 - cutting down grin into smaller pieces
 - more layers between grin and the scary internet
 - "grin server" might become very stable if it only does one thing, good
 - grin could realistically be single-threaded
 - less context switching
 - protects grin/mining processes from some network-based attacks
 - TravisCI might be faster if we move out the p2p part
 

Riding on existing libs would save a lot of time. Maybe even an easy path to GUI wallets.

* https://ws-rs.org/
  - Event-driven WebSockets for rust
  - Likely the most performant. (Also most stable?)
  - Maybe allows reusing existing code the best, f we don't want to move the p2p part out into a separate service just yet.
  - still rust, so possibly missing out on a chance to attract non-rust programmers to work on grin

* https://github.com/bitpay
  - maybe doable to only patch in grin's data formats?
  - bitcore-p2p
	- CoPay wallet (often used by alts)

* https://socket.io/blog/socket-io-p2p/
	- WebRTC, nodejs
	- [C++11](https://github.com/socketio/socket.io-client-cpp), [Swift](https://github.com/socketio/socket.io-client-swift)
	- mature

* http://www.freedomjs.org/
	- multiple p2p backends: WebRTC, XMPP, community provided
	- js. allows code reuse between platforms: nodejs, browsers, Cordova (Android/iPhone/...)

* Something else?
[The awesome p2p list](https://github.com/kgryte/awesome-peer-to-peer)
has a lot to wade through, also things usable for peer discovery:
mDNS local discovery, DHT, service discovery solutions, WebRTC swarm over BLE
that can allow two Android phones to create a transaction locally before either
sends it to a grin miner or cut-through aggregator.

issue.title: [WIP][NET] Add NATPMP support.
issue.body:
Adds minimal support for NATPMP (and removes dependency on external UPnP library). Reference implementation in `miniupnp/libnatpmp`.

WIP but aims to fix #11902 .

events.body: Can someone please assign this issue to me?
@MishraShivendra Just go for it, no need to ask for permission or assignment.

issue.title: NAT traversal support
issue.body:
I couldn't find an issue tracking NAT traversal so I am opening one.

Some discussion already captured in https://github.com/mimblewimble/grin/issues/636

issue.title: Changes to support NAT-PMP
issue.body:
Changes to support NAT-PMP port forwarding based on libnatpmp to address #11902.
**Changes include the following:**
* Porting of [libnatpmp](https://github.com/miniupnp/libnatpmp) files (namely gateway.cpp/.h and natpmp.cpp/.h)
* C++ style wrapper for easier integration
* Changes to disable upnp by default and use NAT-PMP as explained in #11902 (Introducing -portmap switch).

**Test**
```bash
$./src/bitcoind -portmap
```

Note to reviewers are [here](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15717#issuecomment-483001218), need insights.

issue.title: Add IPv6 pinhole support using UPnP / NAT-PMP
issue.body:
Our current UPnP support works for IPv4 by requesting a port forward. It doesn't work with IPv6 when the user is behind a firewall (which was the default for my modem at least).

More recent versions of [libupnp](https://github.com/miniupnp/miniupnp) support requesting a IPv6 pinhole.

I haven't checked if the same could be done with NAT-PMP (#11902). That may be preferable to updating libupnp.

UPnP is baked into the GUI release binaries, though it's turned off by default in the settings dialog.

issue.title: net: Add NAT-PMP port forwarding support
issue.body:
Close #11902
This PR is an alternative to:
- #12288
- #15717

To compile with NAT-PMP support on Ubuntu [`libnatpmp-dev`](https://packages.ubuntu.com/source/bionic/libnatpmp) should be available.

Log excerpt:
```
2020-02-05T20:12:28Z [mapport] NAT-PMP: public address = 95.164.65.194
2020-02-05T20:12:28Z [mapport] AddLocal(95.164.65.194:18333,3)
2020-02-05T20:12:28Z [mapport] NAT-PMP: port mapping successful.
```

See: [`libnatpmp`](https://miniupnp.tuxfamily.org/libnatpmp.html)

---

Some follow-ups are out of this PR's scope:
- mention NAT-PMP library in the version message
- ~integrate NAT-PMP into the GUI~ (already [added](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/18077#issuecomment-589405068))

issue.title: Implement NAT-PMP protocol to improve Private server port forwarding?
issue.body: I've been reading some posts (i.e. https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/11902#issue-282227529)  about how NAT-PMP is much better than UPnP. In my own experience being always behind NAT, software I use with NAT-PMP support work very well (i.,e. qbittorrent). Maybe this could solve some private server issues?
